newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan sugar mills oppose further imports.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan sugar mills oppose further imports.

text.p: The organisation of Pakistani sugar mills said on Thursday no further sugar imports were needed as it did not foresee any shortage during the rest of this year.

Pakistan Sugar Mills Association (PSMA) chairman Abbas Sarfraz Khan said in a statement that any further imports, if needed, should be made near the end of the next sugarcane crushing season in 1998 to supplement stocks.
"PSMA does not foresee any sugar shortage this year," he said.
Khan said domestic sugar production was likely to be 2.388 million tonnes by the end of the crushing season in September, against estimated consumption of 2.75 million tonnes.
Imports of 372,000 tonnes of sugar had been ordered this year, of which 50 percent had arrived and was being supplied to the market.

"Judging from the (import) orders already placed, there is no need for further imports and no reason for quantity or price panic this year," Khan said. The government should make sure that imports were not purchased in excess of needs.
The state-run Trading Corporation of Pakistan (TCP) last Monday invited bids for 50,000 tonnes of white refined crystal sugar to be delivered in two equal shipments by June 30 and July 15.
The TCP said bids would be opened at 11 a.m. (0600 GMT) on May 24.
